payload.instructions:
# Repository Guidelines

## Project Structure & Module Organization
Source code lives in `src`. Routes and layouts use the App Router under `src/app`, with segment folders like `src/app/[lineId]` for dynamic pages and `src/app/api` for server handlers. Reusable UI sits in `src/components`, while feature-specific logic is grouped inside `src/features/<feature>`. Shared hooks (`src/hooks`), database helpers (`src/lib`), and design tokens (`src/styles`) keep cross-cutting concerns centralized. Static assets (logos, favicons) belong in `public`. Keep new modules aligned with this layout so imports remain predictable.

## Build, Test, and Development Commands
- `npm run dev`: Launches the Next.js dev server with React Fast Refresh.
- `npm run build`: Produces an optimized production bundle; run before deploys.
- `npm run start`: Serves the latest build locally for smoke-testing production output.
- `npm run lint`: Executes the project-wide ESLint rules (Next.js core-web-vitals baseline). Treat warnings as errors before opening a PR.

## Coding Style & Naming Conventions
Use modern ES modules with functional React components. Prefer two-space indentation and trailing commas, matching the existing files. Components that render UI should use PascalCase filenames (`ThemeToggle.jsx`), hooks use camelCase prefixed with `use` (`use-mobile.js`), and utility modules go in `src/lib` with hyphenated names. Favor Tailwind classes for styling; co-locate any component-specific CSS in `src/styles` only if a utility class will not suffice. Run `npm run lint` to ensure ESLint (configured in `eslint.config.mjs`) flags accessibility and performance regressions early.

## Testing Guidelines
Automated tests are not yet wired in. When adding them, group specs beside their feature (`src/features/navigation/__tests__/NavMenu.test.jsx`) so intent is obvious. Name files with `.test.jsx` or `.test.js`. For critical flows lacking automation, document manual verification steps in the PR description and exercise them against `npm run start` output. Keep database interactions mocked or pointed at disposable fixtures to avoid mutating shared environments.

## Commit & Pull Request Guidelines
Craft commit subjects in the imperative mood (“Add navigation badges”), roughly 50 characters, with optional detail in the body. Combine related changes rather than batching multiple features. Pull requests should include: a concise summary, linked issue IDs, screenshots or clip recordings for UI changes, and notes on testing performed (`npm run lint`, manual checks, etc.). Request reviews from owners of affected areas (`src/features/<feature>` or shared libs) before merging.

## Environment & Configuration Tips
Local MySQL connectivity is managed via `src/lib/db.js`, which reads `DB_HOST`, `DB_PORT`, `DB_USER`, `DB_PASSWORD`, and `DB_NAME`. Place secrets in `.env.local`; never commit credentials. Tailwind configuration is defined through `components.json` and `postcss.config.mjs`. If you introduce new design tokens, update `src/styles/tokens.css` and keep class names consistent with Tailwind’s utility-first approach.

<INSTRUCTIONS>
# Repository Guidelines

## Project Structure & Module Organization
Source code lives in `src`. Routes and layouts use the App Router under `src/app`, with segment folders like `src/app/[lineId]` for dynamic pages and `src/app/api` for server handlers. Reusable UI sits in `src/components`, while feature-specific logic is grouped inside `src/features/<feature>`. Shared hooks (`src/hooks`), database helpers (`src/lib`), and design tokens (`src/styles`) keep cross-cutting concerns centralized. Static assets (logos, favicons) belong in `public`. Keep new modules aligned with this layout so imports remain predictable.

## Build, Test, and Development Commands
- `npm run dev`: Launches the Next.js dev server with React Fast Refresh.
- `npm run build`: Produces an optimized production bundle; run before deploys.
- `npm run start`: Serves the latest build locally for smoke-testing production output.
- `npm run lint`: Executes the project-wide ESLint rules (Next.js core-web-vitals baseline). Treat warnings as errors before opening a PR.

## Coding Style & Naming Conventions
Use modern ES modules with functional React components. Prefer two-space indentation and trailing commas, matching the existing files. Components that render UI should use PascalCase filenames (`ThemeToggle.jsx`), hooks use camelCase prefixed with `use` (`use-mobile.js`), and utility modules go in `src/lib` with hyphenated names. Favor Tailwind classes for styling; co-locate any component-specific CSS in `src/styles` only if a utility class will not suffice. Run `npm run lint` to ensure ESLint (configured in `eslint.config.mjs`) flags accessibility and performance regressions early.

## Testing Guidelines
Automated tests are not yet wired in. When adding them, group specs beside their feature (`src/features/navigation/__tests__/NavMenu.test.jsx`) so intent is obvious. Name files with `.test.jsx` or `.test.js`. For critical flows lacking automation, document manual verification steps in the PR description and exercise them against `npm run start` output. Keep database interactions mocked or pointed at disposable fixtures to avoid mutating shared environments.

## Commit & Pull Request Guidelines
Craft commit subjects in the imperative mood (“Add navigation badges”), roughly 50 characters, with optional detail in the body. Combine related changes rather than batching multiple features. Pull requests should include: a concise summary, linked issue IDs, screenshots or clip recordings for UI changes, and notes on testing performed (`npm run lint`, manual checks, etc.). Request reviews from owners of affected areas (`src/features/<feature>` or shared libs) before merging.

## Environment & Configuration Tips
Local MySQL connectivity is managed via `src/lib/db.js`, which reads `DB_HOST`, `DB_PORT`, `DB_USER`, `DB_PASSWORD`, and `DB_NAME`. Place secrets in `.env.local`; never commit credentials. Tailwind configuration is defined through `components.json` and `postcss.config.mjs`. If you introduce new design tokens, update `src/styles/tokens.css` and keep class names consistent with Tailwind’s utility-first approach.

</INSTRUCTIONS>

payload.message:
Removed the auto-width heuristics so the Line dashboard table now respects only the manually defined column sizes.

**Changes**
- `apps/web/src/features/line-dashboard/components/data-table/DataTable.jsx:6-14,188-210` updates the component docs and TanStack setup so `createColumnDefs` is memoized solely from the column schema (no filtered-row sizing) and the table comment now reflects config-based widths.
- `apps/web/src/features/line-dashboard/components/data-table/column-defs.js:6-92` drops `computeDynamicWidthHints`, simplifying `createColumnDefs`/`makeColumnDef` to rely exclusively on config + sample values while keeping sorting/alignment intact.
- `apps/web/src/features/line-dashboard/components/data-table/column-defs/dynamicWidth.js:1-37` now just infers widths from config defaults and sensible fallbacks, removing all runtime measurements.
- `apps/web/src/features/line-dashboard/components/data-table/column-defs/config.js:70-127` removes the unused `autoWidth` knobs so only the `width` map controls sizing.
- `apps/web/src/features/line-dashboard/components/data-table/column-defs/steps.js:1-48` aligns the synthetic `process_flow` column with the new sizing helper signature.

**Testing**
- `npm run web:lint` *(fails: workspace uses ESLint 6.4.0 which doesn’t detect the flat `eslint.config.mjs`; need a newer ESLint or legacy config for linting to run).*

Next steps: 1) After upgrading ESLint (or adding a legacy config), rerun `npm run web:lint` to ensure the flat config is honored.

payload.message:
Manual widths now rely solely on config—no leftover inference helpers.

- `apps/web/src/features/line-dashboard/components/data-table/column-defs/dynamicWidth.js:1-14` drops `inferDefaultWidth`/`toSafeNumber`; `resolveColumnSizes` clamps sizes directly from `config.width`, falling back only to the global default text width when a column lacks an entry.
- `apps/web/src/features/line-dashboard/components/data-table/column-defs/config.js:30-70` documents the intended manual width for `process_flow`, so even the synthetic step column is covered without auto-sizing.
- `apps/web/src/features/line-dashboard/components/data-table/column-defs.js:6-74` and `steps.js:33-48` now call the simplified sizing helper (no row samples passed), keeping alignment logic intact but ensuring TanStack columns reflect only the configured widths.

Testing:
- `npm run web:lint` *(fails: ESLint 6.4.0 can’t find a legacy config while the repo ships `eslint.config.mjs`; upgrade ESLint or add the expected config before linting here succeeds).*

You may want to 1) bump ESLint to a version that supports flat configs or 2) add a `.eslintrc.*` shim so `npm run web:lint` can validate changes.

payload.text:
**Planning status handling and color mapping**

I’m thinking about enforcing exactly four statuses with a consistent order and corresponding lighten-to-dark color mapping. I want to update constants with ordered status arrays and color maps, adjust QuickFilters and DataTable components to rely on that order, and ensure fallback colors for unknown statuses. Since this touches multiple files and impacts both filtering and chart coloring, I’ll create a plan to implement these coordinated changes cleanly.

Since this touches multiple files and impacts both filtering and chart coloring, I’ll create a plan to implement these coordinated changes cleanly.

    97	  "var(--chart-4)",
    98	  "var(--chart-5)",
    99	  "var(--chart-6)",
   100	]
   101	const UNKNOWN_STATUS_KEY = "__UNKNOWN__"
   102	
   103	/**
   104	 * @param {{ lineId: string }} props
   105	 */
   106	export function DataTable({ lineId }) {
   107	  /* ──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
   108	   * 2) 데이터/상태 훅
   109	   *    - rows: 서버/쿼리로 가져온 원본 데이터
   110	   *    - filteredRows: QuickFilters + GlobalFilter 적용된 "현재 보이는" 데이터
   111	   * ──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────── */
   112	  const {
   113	    columns,
   114	    rows,
   115	    filter,
   116	    setFilter,
   117	    sorting,
   118	    setSorting,
   119	    isLoadingRows,
   120	    rowsError,
   121	    fetchRows,
   122	    tableMeta,
   123	  } = useDataTableState({ lineId })
   124	
   125	  const { sections, filters, filteredRows, activeCount, toggleFilter, resetFilters } =
   126	    useQuickFilters(columns, rows)
   127	
   128	  const statusSection = React.useMemo(
   129	    () => sections.find((section) => section?.key === "status"),
   130	    [sections]
   131	  )
   132	
   133	  const statusChart = React.useMemo(() => {
   134	    if (!filteredRows || filteredRows.length === 0) {
   135	      return { data: [], config: {} }
   136	    }
   137	
   138	    const counts = new Map()
   139	    const getRowStatus =
   140	      typeof statusSection?.getValue === "function"
   141	        ? statusSection.getValue
   142	        : (row) =>
   143	          normalizeStatus(
   144	            row?.status ?? row?.STATUS ?? row?.Status ?? row?.StatusName ?? row?.status_label ?? null
   145	          )
   146	
   147	    filteredRows.forEach((row) => {
   148	      const normalized = getRowStatus(row)
   149	      const key = normalized ?? UNKNOWN_STATUS_KEY
   150	      counts.set(key, (counts.get(key) ?? 0) + 1)
   151	    })
   152	
   153	    const statusOptions = Array.isArray(statusSection?.options) ? statusSection.options : []
   154	    const fallbackOrderIndex = new Map(statusOptions.map((option, index) => [option.value, index]))
   155	    const optionLabelMap = new Map(statusOptions.map((option) => [option.value, option.label]))
   156	
   157	    const entries = Array.from(counts.entries())
   158	    entries.sort((a, b) => {
   159	      const statusA = a[0]
   160	      const statusB = b[0]
   161	      const seqOrderA = STATUS_ORDER_INDEX.has(statusA)
   162	        ? STATUS_ORDER_INDEX.get(statusA)
   163	        : Number.POSITIVE_INFINITY
   164	      const seqOrderB = STATUS_ORDER_INDEX.has(statusB)
   165	        ? STATUS_ORDER_INDEX.get(statusB)
   166	        : Number.POSITIVE_INFINITY
   167	      if (seqOrderA !== seqOrderB) return seqOrderA - seqOrderB
   168	      const fallbackOrderA = fallbackOrderIndex.has(statusA)
   169	        ? fallbackOrderIndex.get(statusA)
   170	        : Number.POSITIVE_INFINITY
   171	      const fallbackOrderB = fallbackOrderIndex.has(statusB)
   172	        ? fallbackOrderIndex.get(statusB)
   173	        : Number.POSITIVE_INFINITY
   174	      if (fallbackOrderA !== fallbackOrderB) return fallbackOrderA - fallbackOrderB
   175	      if (a[0] === UNKNOWN_STATUS_KEY && b[0] !== UNKNOWN_STATUS_KEY) return 1
   176	      if (a[0] !== UNKNOWN_STATUS_KEY && b[0] === UNKNOWN_STATUS_KEY) return -1
   177	      return a[0].localeCompare(b[0])
   178	    })
   179	
   180	    const data = entries.map(([status, value], index) => {
   181	      const label =
   182	        optionLabelMap.get(status) ??
   183	        (status === UNKNOWN_STATUS_KEY
   184	          ? "Unknown"
   185	          : STATUS_LABELS[status] ?? status?.replace(/_/g, " ") ?? "Unknown")
   186	      const fill =
   187	        STATUS_COLORS[status] ??
   188	        STATUS_CHART_FALLBACK_COLORS[index % STATUS_CHART_FALLBACK_COLORS.length]
   189	      return {
   190	        status,
   191	        label,
   192	        value,
   193	        fill,
   194	      }
   195	    })
   196	
   197	    const config = data.reduce((acc, item) => {
   198	      acc[item.status] = { label: item.label, color: item.fill }
   199	      return acc
   200	    }, {})
   201	
   202	    return { data, config }
   203	  }, [filteredRows, statusSection])
   204	
   205	  /* ──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
   206	   * 3) React 19 스타일: 필요한 지점만 useMemo
   207	   * ──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────── */
   208	  const columnDefs = React.useMemo(() => {
   209	    const firstVisibleRow = filteredRows?.[0]
   210	    return createColumnDefs(columns, undefined, firstVisibleRow)
   211	  }, [columns, filteredRows])
   212	
   213	  // 글로벌 필터 함수: 컬럼 스키마가 바뀔 때만 재생성
   214	  const globalFilterFn = React.useMemo(
   215	    () => createGlobalFilterFn(columns),
   216	    [columns]
   217	  )
   218	
   219	  /* 페이지네이션/컬럼 사이징 로컬 상태 */
   220	  const [pagination, setPagination] = React.useState({ pageIndex: 0, pageSize: 15 })
